review.title: Reservoir Characterization: A Machine Learning Approach
review.abstract: Reservoir Characterization (RC) can be defined as the act of building a reservoir model that incorporates all the characteristics of the reservoir that are pertinent to its ability to store hydrocarbons and also to produce them.It is a difficult problem due to non-linear and heterogeneous subsurface properties and associated with a number of complex tasks such as data fusion, data mining, formulation of the knowledge base, and handling of the uncertainty.This present work describes the development of algorithms to obtain the functional relationships between predictor seismic attributes and target lithological properties. Seismic attributes are available over a study area with lower vertical resolution. Conversely, well logs and lithological properties are available only at specific well locations in a study area with high vertical resolution.Sand fraction, which represents per unit sand volume within the rock, has a balanced distribution between zero to unity.The thesis addresses the issues of handling the information content mismatch between predictor and target variables and proposes regularization of target property prior to building a prediction model.In this thesis, two Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based frameworks are proposed to model sand fraction from multiple seismic attributes without and with well tops information respectively. The performances of the frameworks are quantified in terms of Correlation Coefficient, Root Mean Square Error, Absolute Error Mean, etc.

sections.heading: 1.2 Research Issues
sections.text: From the literature review cited above, the problems associated with precise characterization of the reservoir are as follows: Integrating the dataset: Creating the master dataset that combines information from different sources before modeling and classifying lithological properties. Thus, for example, borehole logs and seismic attributes should be collected by different methods with different sampling rates and resolutions; the problem of ambiguous sampling of borehole and seismic data, different scales of seismic, borehole data and other reservoir data should also be adequately addressed by developing generalized methods that can be independent of the characteristics of the target reservoir. Thin reservoir units: Area with thin-bedded stacked reservoirs (sand / shale units) makes it difficult to identify changes in the sand / shale fracture. Poor data quality: Data obtained from a study area with poor data mixes or a limited number of reservoirs is not helpful.

sections.heading: 1.3 Objectives
sections.text: The primary objective of this work is to develop algorithms for determining the functional relationships between seismic prediction attributes and lithological target properties (e.g. sand content, water saturation, etc.), which can be further subdivided into: Integration of seismic and borehole datasets introduction6 Considering the problem related to the discrepancy between the information content of seismic attributes and lithological properties Predicting the variation in lithological properties of seismic attributes Predicting class names of lithological properties of seismic attributes

sections.heading: 1.4 Contributions of the Thesis
sections.text: In this thesis, sand fractions and water saturation are used as target variables to develop prediction and classification frameworks from borehole logs and seismic attributes. The main contributions of this thesis are as follows: Development of a pre-processing scheme to improve the predictibility of machine learning algorithms by information filtering to predict a lithological property (e.g. sand fraction) from seismic attributes Development of a complete framework to perform a highly guided prediction of sand fractions from seismic attributes Development of a classification framework to classify water saturation from borehole logs Modification of the above classification framework to classify water saturation from seismic attributes.

sections.heading: 1.5 Organization of the Thesis
sections.text: The thesis is organized as follows: Chapter 2 discusses a pre-processing scheme with a regularization level to improve the mapping between predictor seismic attributes and target lithological properties; Chapter 3 presents two frameworks to model the variation of water saturation (class low / class high); then discusses a modification of the framework with seismic attributes as predictor variables; Chapter 5 concludes the thesis by predicting the discussion and future possibilities of water saturation (class low / class high); and a modification of the framework with seismic attributes as predictor variables.

sections.text: The integrated dataset of seismic attributes and sand fraction at four well sites, which is generated after the pre-processing phase as described in Chapter 2, is used in this study. The predictor attributes used in this study are three seismic variables such as seismic amplitude, seismic impedance and instantaneous frequency, and the target variable is the sand fraction. The available borehole data along with the 3-D seismic attributes were used to evaluate the proposed pre-processing phase using a methodology (Fig. 3-3) consisting of three stages, i.e. pre-processing, training and post-processing. sections.heading: 3.3.2 The Proposed Framework
sections.text: Furthermore, the vertical resolution of the seismic attributes is lower than that of the borehole logs due to the longer sampling interval. Generally, seismic data is helpful for modelling a reservoir, but it is difficult to estimate the vertical distribution of deposit properties using seismic signals [11], [12]. Therefore, information from both seismic and borehole logs is necessary to characterize a high-resolution deposit property in both vertical and horizontal directions. For example, sand / slate fracturing, porosity, permeability and saturation are important petrophysical properties that are used in detail in interpreting hydrocarbon reserves. Therefore, modelling such a deposit characteristic for sand is crucial.

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Discussion
sections.text: The aim of the present study is to establish a well-structured prediction of a reservoir property using the MANN concept over a single network while working on a large and complex dataset. Section 3.3 outlined the performance of the proposed workflow together with ANN by blindly estimating the sand portion based on the three seismic attributes (seismic impedance, amplitude, and immediate frequency).The presented results show that the proposed workflow exceeded ANN in terms of higher correlation coefficients, reduced error measurements, and low program execution time by successfully calibrating a functional relationship between seismic and logical signals corresponding to each zone. Thus, the MANN concept can be selected in the case of complex large datasets via ANN. Post-processing of the predicted sand portion realistically improves visualization. sections.heading: 4.2 Development of a Framework to Classify Water Saturation from Well Logs
sections.text: The first important contribution of this chapter is to propose a general framework based on SVDD [65], [66] to characterize water saturation from input drilling logs. Next, a comparative analysis is presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed classification method vis-à-vis other classifiers (discriminant [110], [114], naive Bayes [110], [115], supporting vector-machine-based classifiers [116], [117]). The rest of Section 4.2 is structured as follows: First, the data used in this study are described; then, the proposed classification framework is described; then, a brief description of the performance evaluators used in this work is given; then, experimental results are reported; finally, we close this chapter with a discussion and future scope.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 Data Description
sections.text: The borehole data includes several protocols such as gamma radiation content (GR), bulk density (RHOB), P-sound (DT), neutron porosity (NPHI), spontaneous potential (SP), acoustic impedance (AI) and different resistance protocols such as low resistance (RT), medium resistance (RM) and low resistance (RS) protocols. The characteristics of the reservoir, e.g. sand fraction, water saturation classification 51 porosity, water saturation, oil saturation, etc. are derived from these protocol properties.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 Proposed Classification Framework
sections.text: In recent years, SVDD and other kernel-based algorithms have been described as popular techniques for classifying unbalanced datasets in the field of hyperspectral image processing, outlier detection, document classification, etc. In this paper, an attempt was made to construct an SVDD-based framework for classifying reservoir properties using an unbalanced geological dataset. The proposed general framework, which includes three steps, namely - 1) classification of water saturation 52-data preparation, 2) preliminary analysis, and 3) training and testing, is briefly discussed in Figure 4-1.

sections.text: This paper proposes a complete framework based on SVDD to classify water saturation from borehole logs on the basis of an unbalanced geological dataset. Comparative analyses in this section have shown that the proposed method has exceeded existing classification algorithms in terms of performance evaluators (g-metric averages and program execution time), and this work can be expanded to include seismic attributes as input into the classifier-based model. Integrating the seismic and limited number of available borehole data will help generate 3D volumes representing high and low water saturation values throughout the field.Classification of water saturation57

sections.heading: 4.3 Development of a Framework to Classify Water Saturation from Seismic Attributes
sections.text: Water saturation is an important property in the field of reservoir engineering. Therefore, a satisfactory classification of water saturation due to seismic attributes is advantageous for the characterization of the reservoir. However, the diverse and nonlinear nature of the underground attributes complicates the classification task. Section 3.2 has proposed a generalized SVDD-based new classification framework to divide the water saturation from four borehole protocols into two classes (class high and class low). In this section, the above framework is modified to use three seismic attributes such as seismic impedance, amplitude hull and seismic sweetness as predictor variables. As in the previous section, g-metric means and the execution time of the program are used to quantify the performance of the modified framework together with the established monitored classifiers.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Data Description
sections.text: This section uses the data set corresponding to the four wells (well A, well B, well C and well D) as described in section 4.2. As an extension of the work performed in section 4.2, seismic attributes corresponding to the study area are included as predictor variables instead of well logs to obtain a map of water saturation level. There are five seismic attributes derived from the same study area, such as seismic impedance, amplitude, immediate frequency, amplitude hull and seismic sweetness. However, seismic impedance, amplitude hull and seismic sweetness are selected via amplitude and immediate frequency using relief algorithm.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Proposed Classification Framework
sections.text: In this section, a classification framework is designed to classify the water saturation of seismic attributes on the basis of an unbalanced geological dataset. Workflows comprise four steps: data preparation, preliminary analysis, training and testing, volumetric classification and visualization of the water saturation map as shown in Figure 4-8. The steps of the proposed framework are designed by modifying the work performed in Section 4.2 and briefly described in this section. Research carried out in this study is carried out on a 64-bit MATLAB platform installed on an Intel (R) Core (TM) i5CPU @ 3.20 GHz workstation with 16 GB of RAM. The following sections describe the experimental results obtained at each step of the proposed framework.

sections.heading: 4.3.2.1 Data Preparation
sections.text: As shown in the figure (Figures 4-8), the process begins with data acquisition and integration of seismic and borehole data. First, the borehole logs are converted into the time domain from the depth domain, using the time-depth relationships available at the four borehole sites. Then, seismic attributes are extracted from the seismic volume at the four borehole sites. It is determined that the sampling intervals of these data sets (seismic and borehole logs) are different, for example, the seismic patterns are sampled at an interval of two milliseconds, while the sampling interval of the borehole logs is 0.15 milliseconds. Therefore, we interpolate the limited seismic signals at 0.15 milliseconds (sampling intervals).

sections.heading: 5.2 Future Scope
sections.text: The following seems to be a promising area for future research. As the selection of the initial parameters of machine learning algorithms is critical for acceptable performance, it would be interesting to automate the initialization parameters by a suitable metaheuristic algorithm based on post-processing the model rather than spatial filtering of predicted lithological properties. Quantifying the uncertainty associated with the characterization of reservoirs is of interest: some interesting work has been reported in [121], [122] on the application of quantification uncertainty in the characterization of reservoirs. These publications can be used as a guide for investigating uncertainty analyses related to modeling and the data acquisition process of reservoir characterization.67

metadata.abstractText: ‘Reservoir Characterization (RC)’ can be defined as the act of building a reservoir model that incorporates all the characteristics of the reservoir that are pertinent to its ability to store hydrocarbons and also to produce them. It is a difficult problem due to non-linear and heterogeneous subsurface properties and associated with a number of complex tasks such as data fusion, data mining, formulation of the knowledge base, and handling of the uncertainty. This present work describes the development of algorithms to obtain the functional relationships between predictor seismic attributes and target lithological properties. Seismic attributes are available over a study area with lower vertical resolution. Conversely, well logs and lithological properties are available only at specific well locations in a study area with high vertical resolution. If a functional relationship can be calibrated between seismic signals and lithological properties at available well locations, then distribution of these properties across the study area can be predicted from available seismic information. Depending on the distribution of the lithological properties, a dataset can be classified into two categories – balanced and imbalanced. Sand fraction, which represents per unit sand volume within the rock, has a balanced distribution between zero to unity. On the other hand, water saturation, oil saturation etc. has an imbalanced distribution skewed at one and zero respectively. The investigation about the sand fraction (balanced distribution) variation over the study area has been attempted as a prediction problem; whereas, the distribution of water saturation (balanced distribution) has been approached as a classification (Class low/ Class high) problem in this work. The thesis addresses the issues of handling the information content mismatch between predictor and target variables and proposes regularization of target property prior to building a prediction model. In this thesis, two Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based frameworks are proposed to model sand fraction from multiple seismic attributes without and with well tops information respectively. The performances of the frameworks are quantified in terms of Correlation Coefficient (CC), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Absolute Error Mean (AEM), etc. After successful completion of sand fraction prediction, a one-class classification framework based on Support Vector Data Description (SVDD) is proposed to classify water saturation from well logs. The designed framework is modified to include seismic variables as predictor attributes to obtain the variation of water saturation over the study area. In other words, the class labels (Class low/Class high) of water saturation belonging to a well location can be predicted from seismic attributes by the modified classification based framework. The proposed frameworks have outperformed other supervised classification algorithms in terms of g-metric means and program execution time (in seconds).
